title: Between 4 February 2022 and 4 June 2022, what will be the highest seven-day average for daily new COVID-19 cases in New Zealand?
preds: mid-march peak was 22k - recent stats are significantly blow that with short time period before close of reporting

22,000 cases on March 6, 2022 looks to be the highest case number reported, and after that, the numbers have dropped dramatically. I concur with the consensus opinion that this date will mark the highest 7-day average in the period in question.
The possibility of a late-stage increase in cases to bring the 7-day average over 40,000 is approaching zero.
Tbh, I'm basing my initial forecast on the crowd's forecast.

With a month left to run a new wave is less likely to peak above 40,000 before June 4th. The high rate of vaccination seems to be working against a widespread level of disease that causes people to take a test. The reporting problem is also a factor that I have noted before.
There is still a very small chance of another wave kicking off in the next ~20 days and then spiking the average to >40k within the window of the forecast. That seems exceedingly unlikely though.
i think i'll go ahead and up this to the final answer
Chance of a BA.2 spike could lead to new highs, but highly unlikely to double by June.
question now is just whether they'll be able to get it down fast enough that any risk of exploding this summer is drowned by the dearth of victims.

Almost arbitrary at this point.
The number of new cases largely depends on the number of new tests (which appears to be very low across an industrialized nation such as NZ), since test positivity rate is at >75%.
r0, despite having sunk below 2.0 again, is still above 1.5 and thus in a phase of highly exponential growth, with potential new daily record case reports within 10 days.
Cases look to have peaked around 21k.

The 7 day average breached 20k so it is a matter of whether it will double in the next few months. That depends on how many people will report the results of RAT tests online. 40% of the population will not be motivated to help the government so while the true infection rate will exceed 40K I think the reported level will peak shy of that.
looks about like it topped out
ok i was presuming it was ending faster than it appears to be due to some periodicity every weekend, so this might could still go another 20k, just less likely imo.
about to call it there... unless there's another spike, this one's cooling off

NZ is over 18k today.  I totally misjudged this one.  will definitely go over 20k, but not sure if it will get to 40k, that s a big leap.  This peak seems to be petering out.  and a second peak feels like it wouldn’t be as high as this one The 32k day looks to be a catch up of the 0 value day to me, which would but the series of three days that show 0, 15k, 32k at probably something like 12k, 15k and 17k it it was to follow the curve. The flattening out of the curve can be seen, but unless there is a dramatic drop in the next couple of days to balance out the 4 over 20k, it will reach 20k.

On Feb 20th I predicted a peak day of ~23k. We hit 32k on one day but are hovering around 24k per day now. Unless there is some sort of second wave, it seems like we'll see a slow decrease back down to normal levels. With that the 7 day rolling peak will very likely cross 20k once that day at 0 (likley a data error) is gone (in two days).  Dropping my 10-20k to 5% (in the case we don't quite cross 20k due to a faster decline or data error) and dropping 40k+ to 10% (in the case a second wave happens).

It's now a virtual certainty this will go over 20,000: The Last 7 days as of now recorded:
3rd March: 22,582
2nd March: 23,180
1st March: 24,106
28th Feb: 32,674
27th Feb:15,015
26th Feb:0
25th Feb: 13,625 Tomorrow's (4th March) count if over 22,442, would push the 7 day average above 20,000. However that would represent only a tiny decrease from today and the signs are that the case counts are currently dropping faster than that (although not enough to say that with much confidence). So there is a chance this hits 20k tomorrow. I'm assuming that '0 cases' day was a problem with reporting but I can't find anything about it online. In any case it doesn't seem to happen every week or anything in the OurWorldInData chart. In two days time that 0 case count from the 26th Feb will no longer be included in the calculation. That will mean that to get a 7 day average above 20k, 22,442 cases have to be reported in todays data + tomorrows data. Unless we see another reporting error, it seems extremely unlikely this will not be the case. Even if we do see a reporting error it is unlikely that threshold won't be breached in the coming days. On top of this, the curve appears to be bending now when viewed on a log scale, so I am quite confident NZ is near the peak of cases.

I just read in the NY Times that "experts" assume that half of the population of NZ will get COVID in the next three months! EDIT:  Half is 2.5m.  Assume a 25%-50%-25% distribution of cases over those 3 months.  (I have no basis for that assumption except that case counts double then fall as dramatically as they rose.)  That would mean that there might be 1.25m cases in May or about 42k per day.

7-day avg is 18,740!
Today's new cases = 23,183!
Total in NZ = 188.7k . . . that's about 1/4th of the population which I estimate is vulnerable because they haven't been vaccinated, including 5% for breakthrough infections.
Going up on bin 5, if the peak comes in the next week or so it seems less likely that bin 6 will be reached.
Thursday 3rd March and we already have a seven day average of over 17,000 - another update is required.
The backlog in testing, the rapid expansion in availability of RATs and high % positive tests suggest the peak is still some way off but unlikely to go above 40,000.

7-day rolling average is already over 14k. Doubling rate seems to be around 3.5 days. Possible slackening in the rate of spread but a little too soon to tell. We are still on track for cases to hit 24k per day by 3 March. The wave is likely to last for another doubling period beyond that, as it has been going for less than 4 weeks so far (Omicron waves in other countries have lasted 4-5 weeks). So a not insignificant chance of cases going over 40k per day.

I was reasonably high from the start but I suspect this might beat my expectations. Why will NZs peak per capita be greater than most other nations? I suspect that we are just more willing to get tested.
The numbers this weekend were bit wonky. It looked like things were tapering off, but that doesn't seem to be true now that we've hit a day at 32k. Changing back to numbers based on my prior math.
Forgot about this question for a few days because of all the focus on Ukraine, but Omicron does not rest...
Today's 20,000 new cases caught me by surprise. My trust in people acting prudently has been falsely placed.

Another day with new cases around 14,600.  
It appears that the rate of increase in new cases is slowing.  
The 7 day average is now 7.5k+
With high positivity rates and more testing capacity coming online there is a growing chance of 20k+ but will be very surprised if a7-day average over 40,000 is reached

I am finding this hard to predict. Testing capacity is now high with RATs and people want to get tested. I suggest that NZ could exceed modelled expectations!
Still expected to have another 2 weeks until peak numbers and beginning to decline with nearly 20000 reported today
https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/national/462513/covid-19-update-nearly-20-000-community-cases-373-in-hospital-9-in-icu

15% positivity rate and 25,000 being conducted/day. Test volumes so far have not scaled with the outbreak, hence the +ve % increase. I am thinking a lot of this wave is now going undetected. Some sources are saying capacity has been reached [ https://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/news/covid-19/covid-19-omicron-outbreak-what-the-next-phase-of-the-omicron-plan-will-look-like/ ] Interestingly it looks like capacity max limits were based on pooled testing, e.g. you batch 10 specimens together and test the lot to see if any are positive, and then if it indicates positive you re-test all the specimens to find those which are. However this doesn't work when the proportion of positive specimens is so high, since you actually end up having to retest every batch. So it sounds like true capacity might have been reached. Given that there are probably only a few weeks (maybe less) until the peak, it's quite possible that capacity will only increase after the bulk of cases. With that in mind, I think it's unlikely we'll see 66% positivity to resolve this in bin 5 or 6 at 30k tests/day. I think the biggest risk here, that may allow the question to resolve in bin 5 is if RATs start being included in confirmed case definition (found here https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-information-health-professionals/case-definition-and-clinical-testing-guidelines-covid-19 )

https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/covid-19-omicron-outbreak-new-zealands-reproduction-number-highest-in-the-world-model-shows/42IV4CWYYKETV4JEMQAVXM5Q5A/ I read today that they consider the omicron outbreak to have begun on Jan 7th.
Just shy of 15k new cases were reported today.  71k cases total to date.
About 3.74 people are getting omicron from each existing case, which means THEORETICALLY we could be looking at about 60k cases/day in 3 days.   Shocking!  I'm radically changing my forecast, again!

Constraint on capacity for PCR testing is probably the key reason for slowing in the rise of numbers (note 25%ish positivity rate on testing), once self=reportable RATs are more widely available numbers will continue to rise but still seems less likely that a 7 day average over 20000 will be reached

The slowdown in yesterdays numbers could be because of lower reporting and fewer tests on the weekend or it could mean we are hitting the peak. If we are hitting the peak before the single-day surpasses 15k, it seems less likely. Bumping up the 10-20k bucket and moving down the 40k+ bucket

The curve is actually accelerating and now doubling every day. It was 12k yesterday, which means my assumption of 23k will likely be surpassed by tomorrow. We're now into the territory where some of those assumptions need to be questions. I had assumed a 70% effectiveness of the vaccine, but perhaps it is much lower.
way up these days with not much sign of slowing down yet... i think it'll take about another week to start slowing and dropping.

CAVEAT:  Maybe I'm reading the wrong chart/data because @GMR says that there were 12k cases today and the 7 day average is 4400. HOWEVER, from what I found/saw
7 day average is 2917 today.
New cases per day are exceeding 6k. Playing around with numbers . . . There's 5.084m people in NZ Recently, I read that in NZ
-88.5% have had 1 dose of the COVID vaccine
-77.7% have had 2 doses
-43% have gotten booster shots So, about 584k have not gotten any shots and could get it
I've read that about 5% of cases of omicron are in vaccinated people, so there might be another 225k cases in vaccinated people.
That gives us a total of 809k people who might get it sooner or later. For the 7-day average to exceed 5k, there would need to be at least 35k cases in those 7 days.
35k = .68% of the total population and 4.3% of the susceptible population in NZ
Since there were more than 6k new cases reported today, this bin is definitely possible soon For the 7-day average to exceed 10k, there would need to be at least 70k cases in those 7 days
70k = 8.6% of the susceptible population would have to get it IN ONE WEEK For the 7-day average to exceed 20k, there would need to be at least 140k cases in those 7 days
140k = 17.2% of the susceptible population would have to get it IN ONE WEEK Jacinda Ahern is saying that the peak is expected in mid-March and may be around 30k cases a day; I'm having a hard time seeing so many cases in a country with such a high vaccination rate when there are measures being taken to slow spread.
Growth remains in the high 20% per day, so increasing chances of cracking 20k
Now that it has been made clear that RATs will be counted as well as PCR tests I can be more confident in a higher forecast.

Re-reading the question I see that we're looking at a 7 day average and not a peak daily number. My math before expected a peak of 23k, but the average might end up. being a bit lower based on averaging the days around it, and my model's curve didn't have a slowed growth at the end as I was just looking for the peak at the current rate. I'm adjusting my prediction down a bit to put 10-20k as the most likely. I think the chances that we cross 10k are still really good (>68%) but we'll find out in the next few days based on how the growth rate slows . The growth rate has also slowed down from 25% to ~20%, which might suggest we're closer to the peak than I had thought. I'd expect the peak of this wave to hit sometime between Feb 28 and March 5. Leaving room at the top end for another wave before June

Updating because I believe my prior was wrong. I was looking an Omicron's spike elsewhere and assuming a similar growth in New Zealand. Their other waves are so small that this isn't an accurate prior - both because the first numbers are smaller and because it means their population has less illness-produced immunity (which seems to be the more effective immunity against Omicron). As a new prior I want to look at a the percent of the population that has caught COVID in similar countries, assume some effectiveness of the vaccine and model out a spread to figure out the peak. New Zealand has only had ~6k cased per 1M people, Australia (a neighbor with a similar climate) has had ~116k, Japan (another island with a similar climate on the opposite side of the equator) has had 35k, Uruguay and Argentina (similar latitude) have had 233k and 192k respectively. The average of those is 144k. Let's assume the vaccine regiment New Zealand has had is ~70% effective (based off of https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMc2119270), that would mean that we could expect an uncontrolled outbreak to reach 43k people. If we model that in a normal exponential distribution growing at ~25% per day (current rate for last ~2 weeks) a total infected amount of 216k (144k per million * 1-0.7 for vaccine effectiveness * 5 (population of 5 million) gives us a peak day of ~23k, at which point this wave would have infected 118k people, and then we'd watch the back half of the curve. Adjusting my estimate towards that.
Adjustment to my priors. The trick is going to be to  estimate the peak given the relaxed attitude of the unvaccinated.

The UK had a base rate of 50-60k cases per day before Omicron hit last year. That went to to 180k at its highest. The US had a base rate of around 120k, which hit 800k. Belgium 5-10k -> 52k.
Australia 3k -> 100k
South Korea 3-6k -> 87k and still rising
Poland 12k -> 44k
South Africa 500 -> 22k These countries are not necessarily comparable in terms of demographics, vaccination rates, reliability of statistics or COVID control policies. But you can see that Omicron can lift the infection rate by 4 to 44 times the base rate of infections. That's a very wide range. The sharpest rise in a developed country from that list was in Australia, which had had very minimal infections before Omicron but had vaccinated around 80% of its population. It just goes to show that vaccinations do not prevent infections - only severe illness. New Zealand started with a base rate of 100-500 cases. It had a slightly better rate of vaccinations then Australia. If multiplying by only 4x, it should see 1200-1500 cases per week by the peak. But if its Omicron wave looks anything like Australia's (x33) it could go as high as 15k per week. If it looks like South Africa's (x44), it could go as high as 22k. New Zealand has a much smaller population than Australia or South Africa (respectively 5m, 25m and 59m). It has fewer big cities and appears to enjoy tighter social compliance with COVID restrictions. It seems less likely to experience the same extreme jump in cases as those countries. Another angle is to looking at how far cases are doubling and when the Omicron wave started. At the moment New Zealand's cases seem to be doubling every 4 days. Its Omicron wave began around 7 Feb with cases around 200, and 12 days later they reached 1,600, 200 X 2 X 2 X2 = 1,600, so three doublings in 12 days, i.e. doubling every four days). If the wave peaks after a total 4-5 weeks, which is what happened in the UK and South Africa late last year, there is time for another 3-4 doublings, maybe a touch more. Cases are currently 1,600 per day, so x2x2x2 gives us 12,800 cases. Another doubling gives us 25,600 cases (and the 'touch more' might bring us over 30,000, or even over 40,000). Jacinda Ardern therefore seems to be pretty on the money when she says there is a high degree of unpredictability, and that cases could peak between 10k and 30k per day. She was looking at South Australia as a comparator, which seems like a reasonable assumption.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/08/new-zealand-omicron-wave-likely-to-peak-in-march-with-up-to-30000-cases-a-day-says-ardern I think she is downplaying things to cite the 10k figure, and there is a modest chance the figure could go well over 30k.
Gosh, at 1,600 per day now and the chart shows no sign of slowing down. Assigning 10% to a slowdown happening before 2k, 60% that it happens before 5k but allowing 29% that it crosses that.

Now at 1600 and still increasing rapidly.  Highest number of tests in one day for NZ is ~40k. Currently averaging about 25k, with test positivity skyrocketing. According to [ https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-current-cases ] only PCRs count for official cases in NZ, so unless capacity is sufficient and is currently under-used, it could have an impact on the ability to accurately record the number of cases. We will see when this happens if test positivity % increases but the case count remains static.  Given we are seeing a doubling every 3 days or so, I'd expect to see 6000/day cases by next Saturday.

At the end of last week there were 230 schools dealing with Covid cases. While everyone over 8 needs to wear a mask, this will still be a big infection vector that is only just starting to build.
https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/in-depth/450874/covid-19-data-visualisations-nz-in-numbers
The rate spread is growing steadily. The main problem is guessing when the wave will peak. That is dependent on psychological/sociological factors rather than political ones.

https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/covid-19-omicron-outbreak-cases-tracking-towards-peak-in-mid-march-expert/H3HKWZ42DIIIDTH22NQQ64LVVU/
. . . 
New Zealand is on track to see 10,000 Covid-19 infections a day - with most cases to be recorded in Auckland - by mid-March, an expert predicts.
. . . 
University of Otago professor Michael Baker says the trend of increases in case numbers was exactly what was expected and indicated the outbreak could peak in March. "[It has been] three weeks since community transmission was really established in New Zealand and we saw that initial uptick in cases," Baker told the New Zealand Herald.
~~~~~
COMMENT:  WOW, I've really been behind the 8-ball on this one.  Today's total is over 1900 cases.
New Zealand is currently at 1500+ cases per day and increasing for the past few days.  Based on trends in other countries, Omicron peaks in about 2 weeks before the 7 day average starts coming down.

Given their responses so far, I expect they'll keep measures in place to keep the cases low. But given what was seen in Australia, even with some controls in place, barring a full lock down the cases will rise quickly, especially will school going back and kids going to school
Probably best to watch case rates every day for the time being...

Revising based on the review of the relative rates with other countries.  Daily rate is now over 1k per day, so need a week of that to sustain the daily average.  Assuming rates will at least double again and sustain for a least a fortnight.   Weill keep revising when we see evidence that rates increase as they have in other countries.

Curious to understand the crowd perception that this will stay below 2000. It's looking like it's going to be over 1000 by the weekend and over 2000 by the end of next week. Even if NZ was to enact draconian restrictions at this point (seems unlikely based on the 'phase 2' plan - [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/14/nz-covid-outbreak-like-nothing-weve-experienced-ardern-says-as-cases-skyrocket ]), it's likely that infections are already at that level and baked in. At current rate of increase NZ ill be in bin 2 by the end of Feb, and bin 3 by mid-March.  The only reservation I have about picking the higher bins is that as we are seeing in the UK, other countries might end mass testing. However I'm sceptical that such a change will happen in NZ so soon where the population is not as desensitived to covid as the rest of the world.

Agree with @GMR, the first bin can almost be ruled out already. A few more considerations on reported case numbers, comparable countries and seasonality. Reported Covid-19 cases are almost always an undercount, rule of thumb could be that for X reported cases there are more than 2X community cases. (Source: Spiegelhalter & Masters, "Covid by Numbers"). So with about 1K cases today in NZ, there are at least 2K in the community. What does it matter for the challenge if half of community cases are always reported? As cases increase, especially if they spike, testing might increase widely and abruptly - thus revealing more and more cases. Countries with similar populations to NZ are Ireland and Norway, arguably. They differ in many other respects of course, but they both hit more than 20K cases recently due to omicron. That was in the winter.
https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-07-19..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&hideControls=true&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Color+by+test+positivity=false&country=NZL~IRL~NOR As NZ approaches colder weather, the risk of community transmission will further increase. Political will for further lockdowns has diminished. NZ has been shielded so far with very low infections. For these 3 reasons, the risks associated with omicron are very high (esp. high transmissibility through a relative un-infected, if highly vaccinated, population).

1160 community cases today and by my estimates a 700 rolling average with a doubling rate that is reducing every day - will be between 3 and 3.5 days at the moment. Could bin1 be ruled out within a week?
Minor changes to my forecast today
Adjusting based on @GMR comment on capacity which also caused me to think through lower pop density and summer and other factors.
https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/national/461470/covid-19-update-record-981-new-community-cases-today Covid-19 update: Record 981 new community cases today

Current rate is around 250 per day, so getting to 2000 seems like a massive explosion is needed.  Yes if things open up and the virus gets circulating it could cause a big wave of infections.  But if it has been circulating for a few weeks and has not taken off like in other countries then NZ behaviour is different. NZ has a population of 5m.  The Uk just about had 100k cases per day out of 68m in Dec 21.  if NZ reached the same rate it would be 7k cases per day.   In addition it is summer in NZ and if the virus is a winter one (not sure there is that much sign of that given it is circulating widely in warmer countries) this is also a possible suppression to cases.  At the very least it being summer and time to be outside will cut down on circulation.
Cases are exploding and Adern seems to have admitted the country now has to live with higher cases and not returned to lockdown which may have been the only way to stop cases rising above bin 1.

Currently at 318 as most other places see COVID numbers drop post-Omicron. Leaving a 25% chance of >2k due to New Zealand not having much immunity from people having caught COVID, but only from vaccines, which seem less effective. Also accounting for the fact that if this wave slows down soon, there could be another wave before June.

Thanks to @JPH I am fixing a math error on my comparison with the UK's highest 7-day rolling average of 181,000 cases in a population of 68,454,000. The equivalent case load in New Zealand would be 15,366 cases in a population of 5,122,000.  Thanks to @GMR for explaining the planned slow- and closely-monitored phased reopening of New Zealand's borders. I am changing my estimates based on this feedback. Many thanks!

NZ is using a similar strategy to Australia and based on the population numbers in NZ I compared the most populated city with the most populated city in Australia and predict it will be lower than that as NZ is more spread out geographically.

Reshuffle based on new modelling, frustration of population, 5 day doubling, 480 cases today, dropping of big events but carrying on with every day events, strong public push to get back to normal, talk of getting back to work sooner

Even with climbing case numbers, the positivity rate is stunningly low. Some in opposition are calling for the government to relax restrictions, but given Ardern's majority in parliament, she may well feel able to withstand the pressure.
spreading out my initial forecast in order to account for the possibilities that something wacko happens (as they may when such volatile systems are involved)
i was multiplying these by 7; oh no... their daily (and so many other islands other than the UK) has been super low
just from the weekly rates they've had over the past few runups

Almost 80% of NZ population has been vaccinated, and more than 30% has been received booster. 
With the easing on the travel restriction and considering that vaccines doesn’t provide perfect protection, I expect spike after March on the number of cases. But I expect they will still less than 2000

Pattern: Compared NZ with Australia (closest in every way), Canada, Ireland for similarity and India (for extreme contrast with a country where response is managed and reporting is transparent, unlike USA and China). Saw a very rough pattern of fast rise, mostly 4x-6x although up to 9x also. Steep rise was (usually) followed by steep decline but the lowest part of the decline was one interval higher on y-axis than where it started.  Assumptions: NZ loves lockdown but due to public pressure after being 2 years in some sort of clampdown, I think it's politically not viable to impose lockdown. Country PM is very responsive to poll ratings, which are lowest currently on account of restrictions. So we can assume status quo until June. International border opening is also very cautious. Public follows rules and in biggest city Auckland there are many ethnicity-based clusters meaning that outbreaks can be contained.  We can 100% expect one more peak. starting from 100 to 600 p/d (@6x growth) and then maybe another one, starting at 150 to 900 p/d. Overall, it should remain under 2000 p/d, and even that number will mark a catastrophe for the country in terms of volumes. Predicting with 95% confidence just in case there is unexpected event.
Going back up on bin 1, the growth in cases doesn't seem to have gone exponential, which makes it much less likely that 2000+ average daily cases will be achieved.

I find this very difficult to forecast. I have underforecast on the UK and overforecast on Canada.
NZ has Omicron and this time they are not going to lockdown like they did with the original or delta.
Estimating the current outbreak on what happened with previous outbreaks will not be a good comparison as the previous ones were stopped or slowed with severe restrictions of movement as the country was shut down.
NZs restrictions for this outbreak have been reduced to occupancy limits, vaccination requirements, contact tracing, mask use, etc.  I would comment that these restrictions are only loosely followed apart from the cancellation of major events that could have been superspreader events. 
https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/
 The other big advantage is that NZ is currently in summer and the population is all outdoors. The international modellers at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation have estimated that infections could peak at 80k per day but this would only correspond to around 11k confirmed and probable cases though the 95% confidence is wide (480 to 37k)
https://covid19.healthdata.org/new-zealand
At the beginning of the outbreak this source had predicted that NZ would have 50k infections by today which was largely criticised within NZ.
https://www.1news.co.nz/2022/02/04/kiwi-expert-explains-why-modelling-for-peak-omicron-cases-missed-mark/
however looking further into the Institutes modelling their cases are bang on track for the 50k infections when you compare to the reported cases.
NZ could do better than the modelling because it doesn't account for the public health measures associated with the red light setting of the covid protection framework. Nor does it account for the reduction of the eligibility time for boosters from 6 months to 3 months.
An interesting exercise is to take the omicron peaks from other countries and scale it to NZs population:
Australia (128k cases) to NZ: 25k cases (note similar in terms of very little prior infection, high vaccination, but Australia fully opened up)
UK (182k) to NZ: 13.7k (have substantial prior infections, fewer boosters, opened up)
Sweden (41k) to NZ: 20k (very different strategies and vaccinations and winter)
USA (81k) to NZ: 12k (low testing rates, high previous infections)
South Africa (23k) to NZ:2k (very low testing, social and economic issues, high prior infections)
Singapore (6k not at peak?) to NZ: 5k (much higher density living but used to these kind of issues, higher vaccination, better public health measures and mask use, possibly a good comparison? note the long low delta peak)
UAE (2.9k) to NZ: 1.5k (very high vaccination, very strong public health measures and mask use, amazingly they have kept omicron lower than their delta) I don't suspect that NZ will get as low as the very compliant countries such as Singapore or UAE, I don't think NZ will be as bad as Australia. @oracle100

I think given Omicron's ability to infect those with previous immunity to different variants either from vaccination or previous infection, I think the UK offers a relatively good model of how this will spread in terms of uncontrolled spread in a population. In the UK, the highest rate reached was ~2700 cases/million per day. For New Zealand's population of ~5 million, that translates to around 13,500 cases. However, Sweden and Denmark have both registered even higher case numbers on a per million basis, which would translate to 20,000 and 35,000 NZ cases respectively.  I think with no new restrictions, bin 4 is the likely high watermark, with bin 5 being slightly less likely but still possible. 40,000 may seem very unlikely but with no restrictions it could happen given virtually the entire population has only vaccine induced immunity. NZ policy at the moment is to remove travel restrictions by October [ https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/02/03/new-zealand-border-reopening-covid/ ]. If this is in an effort to stop the spread of Omicron, it seems naive to assume it will be effective, given how easily it's spread and the foothold it looks to have gained in NZ. In a couple of weeks we should know whether the current contact tracing and isolation have been effective and these travel restrictions still make sense but I doubt that they will be sufficient. I also think we'll have an idea by then if new restrictions are going to be introduced. So with that in mind my intial prediction is going to be that the higher bins will be reached, but I'll re-adjust based on reactions in the country over the next couple of weeks. I don't think looking at multipliers vs previous variants for the same country is very effective, particularly in this case, since New Zealand effectively locked out covid and had very few cases outside of quarantine facilities previously.

@JPH's logic makes sense. 77% of the population is fully vaccinated, but now you have the country opening up again, which will likely cause cases to rise, but by how much?  For comparison, I selected the UK's 7-day rolling average confirmed cases on the Our World in Data page. The UK's 7-day rolling average spiked in early January to 181,000 cases. The UK population is 68,454,000. So the highest 7-day number is 0.003% of the population. New Zealand's population is 5,122,000. 0.003% of New Zealand's population is 154. The current high is just above 200. Am I missing something?  I'm inclined to agree with @SE_Meyer, @Mi and @bogpop who put 100% probability for bin 1.

Because the population is at a high level of vaccination there will be some complacency that will lead to a large number of infections, many of which will be asymptomatic or too mild to notice. How many of these will be detected by official testing to be recorded is the main unknown factor. For that reason these numbers are priors.

2,000 is 10x the last peak and Omicron has mostly caused a peak of 5x in other places. It seems there is a large chance that doesn't happen. It is possible the low infection rates in the past come back to haunt them in the face of Omicron which might breakthrough vaccines and infect the population nonetheless. In case it does, I'm assigning decreasing chances to multiples above that with a projected max of ~20k, which would be 100x the past peak.

New Zealand has adopted a Covid elimination strategy and is now planning to open its borders slowly starting at the end of Feb from low cases levels throughout the pandemic. Cases are currently rising (c250 a day now) even before international travel rules are relaxed. New Zealand has a high vaccination rate and mask adoption but this does not seem to stop Omicron spreading (but does reduce hospitalisation). To exceed bin one, a 7x rise in cases is needed. Other countries saw a 5x (UK, Sweden) to 10x (France, South Africa) rise due to Omicron in a month or less. On this basis it certainly seems possible that cases could rise above bin 1 if behaviour is unchecked. The question then becomes whether stricter measure would and could be adopted in time to rule this out.

This is an interesting question because NZ has never had a seven-day average above 200, which is easily into bin 1. As far as I can tell, however, it also has the most relaxed restrictions (although not restriction-less by any means, https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/) it has had during a peak, particularly considering that it is Omicron that is peaking. NZ also has a fairly high vaccination rate (93% of the over 12 population is double vaxed, https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-vaccine-data). Getting to bin 2 would require 14,000 cases over 7 days, which is nearly equal to the total amount of confirmed cases so far (~17k, https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-current-cases). With a doubling time of ~2-4 days and the current number of daily cases being ~250, this could feasibly happen by the end of February/early March, at which point NZ will also start to re-open its borders (in a limited way, https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-60238867). Bin 3 seems less likely, as do bins 4, 5, and 6, but things can always change quickly with Omicron.
